Federal Court
Layden-Stevenson, J.
November 21, 2006.
Counsel:
Johnson Babalola, for the applicant;
David Cranton, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Johnson Babalola, Toronto, Ontario, for the applicant
John H. Sims, Q.C., Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Toronto, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. Any footnotes found in this case will appear below end of document.

[1]
Layden-Stevenson, J.
: Ms. Jean claims to be a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection on the basis that she had been subjected to domestic violence at the hands of her former common-law spouse. The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) found that state protection was available to Ms. Jean in St. Lucia and it rejected her claim. This is an application for judicial review of that decision.

[2]
Ms. Jean contends that the RPD engaged in a selective reading of the documentary evidence and erred in concluding that strong efforts to confront domestic abuse was a sufficient basis upon which to find that adequate state protection is available. She asserts that the RPD ought to have considered whether such efforts are yielding positive results.

[3]
I have concluded that the RPD engaged in a selective reading of the documentary evidence such that its analysis regarding state protection is deficient. Consequently, the application for judicial review will be allowed.
Background

[4]
Ms. Jean, the mother of three children from a previous relationship, began cohabiting with her common law spouse, Henry John, in October of 2000. In early 2001, Mr. John began drinking and became verbally abusive to Ms. Jean and her children. In September of 2001, after an incident of physical abuse, Ms. Jean and the children left and went to her mothers home. When a contrite Mr. John begged them to come back, they returned to the family home. One week later, the abuse resumed and Mr. John threatened Ms. Jean that he would kill her if she ever left again.

[5]
The abuse (both physical and mental) continued and intensified. Eventually, Ms. Jean sought the assistance of the police and the crisis centre. The police told her to sort it out and the crisis centre could not assist her because it had a long waiting list. Twice, Ms. Jean attended the hospital after episodes of abuse.

[6]
When Ms. Jean and her children again sought refuge at her mothers home, Mr. John repeatedly came to the house threatening to kill her if she did not return home. Ms. Jean left the children with her mother and came to Canada. After her arrival here, through telephone discussions with her mother, she learned that Mr. John had persisted in attending at her mothers home and repeating his death threats against Ms. Jean. Although her mother went to the police, no action was taken.
The Decision

[7]
The RPD seemingly accepted Ms. Jeans evidence as credible but determined that state protection was available. It noted that domestic violence is a problem throughout the world. However, the government in St. Lucia is making strong efforts to address the problem. It noted that St. Lucia is a democratic country. It observed that the police have received sensitivity training regarding domestic violence, the judiciary has been diligent in processing protection orders quickly, and violators have been arrested. St. Lucia has a shelter for victims of domestic violence as well as a crisis center that provides counselling and access to social services. Consequently, there is adequate, albeit not exemplary, state protection available.
Issue

[8]
The sole issue is whether the RPD erred in determining that state protection is available to Ms. Jean.
The Standard of Review

[9]
In previous decisions, I have adopted the pragmatic and functional analysis of my colleague Madam Justice Tremblay-Lamer in  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  Tremblay-Lamer that the applicable standard of review in relation to a finding of state protection is reasonableness.
Analysis

[10]
The RPDs determination was based on information contained in a Response to Information Request (RIR) dated April 25, 2003. The RPD relied primarily upon the positive statements of a relations officer from the Ministry of Home Affairs and Gender Relations for St. Lucia. These comments spoke to a positive shift in the attitudes of police officers and the ongoing gender sensitivity training provided to the police by the government. The RPD highlighted the presence of the womens support centre and the issuance of protection orders.

[11]
The documentation also contained negative comments. The RPD did not refer to, or acknowledge, the statements of the representative of the crisis centre. Those accounts were to the effect that most complaints of domestic violence received by the police were not taken very seriously and were placed on the back burner. The prevailing attitudes of the police and the population in general are that the man of the household is the chief and that he can impose discipline in the home by violent means. There were also declarations that the entire justice system needs to be modernized to reflect the seriousness of domestic violence. Additionally, the documentation contains an admonition that, despite years of promises from the government, there are no legal aid clinics in the country.

[12]
None of the negative information regarding the availability of state protection was addressed. While it is clearly open to the RPD to ultimately prefer the statements of one spokesperson over those of another, in so doing it must first deal with both and provide its reasons for choosing one position over the other. It is not open to it to adopt only the positive statements and totally disregard the negative statements without providing an explanation as to why it has done so. It is settled law that evidence that directly contradicts the findings of the board must be acknowledged:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.).

[13]
I agree that the RPD engaged in a selective review of the documentary evidence. In the absence of an explanation or an analysis of the totality of the information contained in the RIR, the RPDs reasons cannot be said to withstand the scrutiny of a somewhat probing examination. Consequently, the application for judicial review will be allowed. Since this is sufficient to dispose of the application, I need not deal with the other arguments.

[14]
Neither party proposed a question for certification and none arises.
ORDER

[15]
THIS COURT ORDERS THAT
the application for judicial review is allowed and the matter is remitted to a differently constituted RPD for determination.
[End of document]

legal_issues: Whether a determination of available state protection was reasonable given a selective consideration of evidence.
What constitutes sufficient evidence of state protection in the context of domestic violence claims.
The standard of review applicable to findings regarding the availability of state protection.
Whether a decision-making body must address contradictory evidence when assessing the availability of state protection.
factual_background: An individual, referred to as Ms. Jean, claimed to be a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection due to experiencing domestic violence.
Ms. Jean cohabited with her common-law spouse, Henry John, beginning in October 2000.
In early 2001, Mr. John began exhibiting verbally abusive behavior, escalating to physical abuse in September 2001.
Following an incident of physical abuse, Ms. Jean and her children temporarily left the shared residence but returned after Mr. John’s apologies.
The abuse resumed and intensified, including threats of violence against Ms. Jean.
Ms. Jean sought assistance from police and a crisis centre, but received limited support due to police inaction and a waiting list at the crisis centre.
Ms. Jean sought refuge at her mother’s home with her children, but Mr. John repeatedly visited, issuing death threats.
Ms. Jean subsequently left her children with her mother and travelled to Canada.
After arriving in Canada, Ms. Jean learned through her mother that Mr. John continued to visit her mother’s home and repeat his threats.
The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) initially determined that state protection was available in St. Lucia and rejected Ms. Jean’s claim.

Applicants: The RPD engaged in a selective reading of the documentary evidence.
The RPD erred in concluding that strong efforts to confront domestic abuse were a sufficient basis to find adequate state protection.
The RPD ought to have considered whether the efforts to address domestic abuse were yielding positive results.
The RPD failed to acknowledge or address negative comments within the Response to Information Request (RIR) regarding the seriousness with which police treat domestic violence complaints.
The RPD failed to explain why it disregarded negative statements about the availability of state protection.
The RPD did not address the lack of legal aid clinics in St. Lucia.
Respondents: State protection is available to Ms. Jean in St. Lucia.
The government in St. Lucia is making strong efforts to address domestic violence.
St. Lucia is a democratic country.
The police have received sensitivity training regarding domestic violence.
The judiciary has been diligent in processing protection orders quickly.
Violators of protection orders have been arrested.
St. Lucia has a shelter for victims of domestic violence and a crisis center providing counselling and social services.
State protection is adequate, albeit not exemplary.

court_analysis: The court found the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) erred in its assessment of state protection available to Ms. Jean in St. Lucia, specifically by engaging in a selective reading of the documentary evidence.

The RPD relied heavily on positive statements from a government relations officer regarding efforts to address domestic violence, such as police sensitivity training and the existence of support centers and protection orders.

Critically, the RPD failed to acknowledge or address negative statements within the same documentation, including reports that police often did not take domestic violence complaints seriously, prevailing societal attitudes condoning violence within the home, and a lack of legal aid.

The court emphasized that while the RPD could legitimately prefer one source of information over another, it *must* first acknowledge and provide reasoning for disregarding contradictory evidence, citing established legal principle requiring acknowledgement of evidence contradicting board findings.

The court determined that the RPD’s failure to address the negative evidence resulted in reasons that did not withstand scrutiny, rendering the decision unreasonable under the applicable standard of review (reasonableness).
The court applied a 'somewhat probing examination' standard to the RPD’s reasoning, finding it deficient due to the incomplete analysis of the available information.
As a result of the deficient reasoning, the court allowed the application for judicial review and remitted the case to a differently constituted RPD for redetermination.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review is allowed.
The matter is remitted to a differently constituted Refugee Protection Division for determination.
